title: UNFINISHED MARRIAGE PROCEDURE - What is my current status and my rights in case of divorce? HELP!!!
question: Hello,
answers:
You wrote a lot but gave no information that would be relevant to determining your immigration options. Moreover, there is nothing a poster on an internet message board can do to help you, except to advise you to review your facts and options with attorneys.

Relevant information would include:
What is your immigration status right now?

If you are in the US, how did you enter the US?

What immigration petitions/applications have been filed on your behalf?

Do you have anything in your background that would preclude you from getting legal permanent residency?

What is your background? For example, do you have exceptional skills? Are you fabulously rich? Those may be different ways to get immigrant visas to the US.

There is much more that an attorney would need to know before being able to give you informed advice.

I would suggest you contact this attorney:

Henry Posada
8280 Florence Avenue, Ste. 220
Downey, CA 90240
562.904.9080

He is an immigration specialist, does not charge for consultations, and really knows his stuff. With his advice, you take the necessary steps with an family law attorney. I would be glad to help on the family law end of the case if you like. "Family law" includes divorce, separation, support (child and spousal), division of assets and debts, etc.

I do not believe you will find Henry working on weekends. It may take a few days to get an appointment, but he is well worth it. There is much at stake and you want to get it all done in the most advantageous manner possible.

Timothy E. Nilan
Law Offices of Timothy E. Nilan
A Professional Law Corporation
8344 Florence Avenue, Second Fl., Suite D
Downey, CA 90240
562.862.1984 Fax: 562.862.4350

It is impossible to determine whether you are legally married without more specific facts. I suggest you go to department where marriage licenses are kept in the county where you were married and request of copy of your marriage license. If the county has no record of the marriage, then you are not legally married.
